title: Best days to take annual leave 2020: Maximise your time
text:
How to turn 20 days into 49 days of leave in 2020

HOW TO FIND THE CHEAPEST FLIGHTS

Most jobs offer just 20 days of annual leave each year, but if you plan your trips right you can end up with at least 49 days of holidays in 2020.

The secret is to align your days off with public holidays, so you get more time out of the workplace.

For instance, take four days of leave straight after Australia Day and you’ll end up with a total of nine consecutive days off.

In this respect, not all states are created equal, because some are more generous with public holidays.

Residents of Victoria, Western Australia and the ACT can get 55 holiday days in 2020 by applying this method.

But no matter where you live in Australia, you can still run up 49 days on vacation.

You’ll want to get in quick, because your boss isn’t going to let everyone take leave at the same time.

That’s why it’s critical to start plotting out your 2020 holidays now.

Even if you haven’t booked your travel yet, get those leave applications in to your employer.

That said, booking in advance maximises your chances of scoring a bargain, especially for busy periods such as Christmas or long weekends.

BEST DESTINATIONS TO VISIT IN FIVE DAYS

Mark your 2020 dates now.

These are the crucial periods where you’ll want to take time off for maximum value:

• Book in Thursday, January 2 and Wednesday, January 3 as leave to give yourself a five-day break to start the year.

• Take Tuesday, January 28 to Friday, January 31 as leave, and plan an Australia Day holiday to score nine days on the trot.

• Set Monday, April 6 to Thursday, April 9 (the run up to Easter) as leave, and you’ll get 10 days off in a row.

• Take three days off after the Queen’s Birthday (Tuesday, June 9 to Thursday, June 11 in all states except Queensland and Western Australia which use different dates) for another six-day refresher.

• Start your Christmas break from Monday, December 21, and don’t return to work until Monday, January 3. That gives you 16 days off in a row but only uses seven days of leave.

• Book long weekend breaks for Labour Day (or its equivalent in your state), plus any other state-specific long weekends (such as Grand Final Friday in Victoria, Reconciliation Day in the ACT or Western Australia Day) and local holidays (such as show days in Tasmania or race days in the Northern Territory).

Follow this approach and you’ll use your precious 20 days of annual leave to maximum advantage. If you have extra holiday leave owing, you can potentially extend that even further by “boosting” the long weekends.

Sadly, 2020 isn’t the best ever year for this strategy. In 2019, Anzac Day fell in the same week as Easter Monday, making it possible to take 16 days off around Easter while still only using seven days of annual leave. We won’t see that happen again until 2025. But hey, I’ll take what I can get.

Angus Kidman is the editor-in-chief and travel guru for Finder.
